newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch closing debt market report.
newsitem.headline: Dutch closing debt market report.

text.p: Dutch bonds closed firmer on Friday, pushed higher by bargain-hunters buying up small lots.
The 30-year bond ended up 50 basis points at 110.69/89, while the shorter end moved seven basis points higher to 104.08/16.

While some players have returned to the market after the Christmas/New Year break, prices remain volatile in relatively thin volumes and players still appear to be settling on their strategies, dealers said.

"Prices can move up and down 20-30 points during intra-day trading, but I can't give a fundamental direction to these deals," one said, adding that the market was closely watching U.S. movements, hoping to pick up possible new trends.
"Volatile and nervous, Dutch bonds might show a slight rise until the U.S. hikes its (interest) rates," he said.
Dealers noticed some switching out of Jan 2006 bonds into the 8.25 pct Feb 2007s, which some see as the new Dutch 10-year benchmark.
Others think it's too early to indicate a new benchmark, and prefer to wait until the finance ministry details a new bond issue on January 17.
The widening of the 10-year spread with Bunds to -13 basis points from -10 prompted some switching into Germany, dealers said. Some saw this continuing next week.
Trade volume is expected to pick up from Monday.
